messages.content: comfy-plasma is a simple plasma noise generator extension for ComfyUI that can generate various types of noise patterns for image generation.
What types of noise can comfy-plasma generate?
comfy-plasma can generate plasma noise, random noise, greyscale noise, pink noise, brown noise and plasma KSampler noise.
How does the 'Turbulence' parameter affect the plasma noise generated by comfy-plasma?
The 'Turbulence' parameter in comfy-plasma scales the noise clouds in the plasma noise. Lower values result in smoother, larger clouds, while higher values result in more static-like noise.
What does the 'Seed' parameter control in the plasma noise node of comfy-plasma?
The 'Seed' parameter in the plasma noise node of comfy-plasma replicates a specific noise seed on every execution. It can be set to fixed, increment, decrement or randomize.
What is the difference between the 'Default' and 'Rand' distribution types in the Plasma KSampler node of comfy-plasma?

In the Plasma KSampler node of comfy-plasma, the 'Default' distribution type uses torch.randn() which is a Gaussian distributed noise algorithm, while 'Rand' uses torch.rand() which is a truly random noise algorithm that doesn't stick to a single random distribution.
How does the 'Latent Noise' parameter affect the output in the Plasma KSampler node of comfy-plasma?

The 'Latent Noise' parameter in the Plasma KSampler node of comfy-plasma controls the strength of the built-in noise. A value of 0 means no noise is used, and a value of 1 means it's adding all the noise.
What does the 'Denoise' parameter do in the Plasma KSampler node of comfy-plasma?

The 'Denoise' parameter in the Plasma KSampler node of comfy-plasma controls how much the image should be blurred to allow the model to interpret the noise/image with noise. Higher values at high resolutions can induce faces within faces, while lower values will look closer to the input image/noise but prevent faces within faces.
